awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A new sustainable crustacean bait.
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project promises to deliver a convenient, sustainable, cost effective, and environmentally friendly bait for crustacean fishermen, worldwide.  The  patent- pending innovation offers a formulated, synthetic product that mimics scent cues released from traditional fish bait, while offsetting unwarranted ecological impacts of current practices. Specifically, scent cues can be released at variable rates to provide optimal results in addressing fishing methods and preferences in different conditions and regions. Given rising costs of fish due to competition with omega-3 supplements producers, as well as labor and frozen storage costs of obtaining wild bait, and vessel space needed for such bait when fishing, the new bait will save fishermen time, money, and inconvenience. Commercially, cost advantages are likely to generate significant demand in addition to the overall practical advantages. From a societal perspective, a   sustainable,   synthetic product   can   dramatically   reduce "net fishing" for baiting crustacean  traps. Thus, fish could  be   conserved   in the oceanic food chain, and indiscriminate killing of sea turtles, dolphins and other by- catch would be diminished through reduced net fishing practices now employed in the capture of small wild fish traditionally used for crustacean bait.

The objectives of this Phase II research project are: to optimize solubility kinetics of the attractant-releasing matrix; further characterize naturally occurring molecules released by traditional bait fish; and validate product performance to catch indigenous crustacean species in the United States. Field research would focus on concentrations of chemo-attractants required to optimize  manufacturing  formulation  and  direct costs. The intellectual merit of the proposed activity will be the characterization of the chemical basis for cues emitted by piscine, avian and mammalian tissue that most intensely attract crustacean species while developing a range of matrix formulations for optimally releasing such attractants in various fishing conditions. In addition to globally urgent considerations  of  by-catch  and  wild  stock  depletion, the  industry has been struggling with bait sustainability issues. These challenges have intensified with federal and state agencies seeking court orders to regulate catch limits, resulting in reduced supply and higher prices of bait fish. These circumstances frame an ecological and commercial opportunity for this synthetic bait alternative. Reducing the need to capture wild bait fish, as well as delivering cost and logistical advantages to commercial crustacean fisheries are expected to drive rapid market penetration upon completion of product research and development in this Phase II project.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Broader Impact and Societal Benefits of our Research and Development Activities:

Kepley Biosystems Inc. has invented a patent-pending synthetic crustacean bait with the potential to eliminate the use of "bait" fish to attract and trap lobster and crab in the fishing industry. Crustacean traps are typically baited using a vital link in the food chain; these fish, also called forage fish, are small schooling fish routinely caught using gill nets. The global supply of forage fish is rapidly decreasing due to competition from several industries, including aquaculture, barnyard and domestic animal food, omega 3 supplements, and crustacean fishers; the latter of which are estimated to account for at least a third of commercial consumption. The declining supply and increased demand have driven up costs, affecting the future viability of commercial fishing operations. Beyond the impact on fishing communities, pressures on the global forage fish supply are intensifying derivative risks for sea bird, pelagic fish and mammal populations, from whales to polar bears, to seals and walruses, all of which currently require at least half the ocean's supply to maintain sustainability. This has led to a crisis for our customers now facing rising bait prices, erratic availability, new governmental regulations, and destruction to the ocean ecosystems on which their livelihoods depend.

Opportunity:

The opportunity is comprised of both economic and ecologic benefits by refining a product with significant advantages to fishing stakeholders while contributing to global food security and ecosystem sustainability through replenishment of forage fish. In recent years, erratic bait fish prices and shortages have negatively impacted fishing operations worldwide. These challenges have correlated to reductions in "allowable" catch, overfishing, climate change, coastal deterioration, management strategies and increased industrial exploitation. Bait usage and other demands have also led to "catastrophic" forage fish collapses along the U.S. West Coast, as these fish play vital roles in aquatic and coastal ecosystems. While regulations have been required as corrective measures, they have nonetheless imposed hardships on affected fishing communities. An alternative bait solution would alleviate such pressures on struggling fishing operations.

Goals of Our Work:

This Phase II and TECP supplement resulted in the creation and optimization of an alternative, synthetic bait that mimics naturally occurring molecules that attract aquatic species to traditional bait, typically comprised of forage fish. The development of this product directly contributes to economic development of the U.S. fishing sector by providing a product that would reduce and stabilize operating costs, enhance efficiency and replace a heretofore erratic supply of wild-caught bait, while helping ensure ecosystem sustainability. Tailored to each segment, a reliable supply of affordable, easy-to-use, manufactured bait provides advantages to commercial, recreational, and community fishing operations while conserving precious ocean resources. Adoption of this technology could lead to bait fish biomass restoration within a decade by replacing their use with sustainable synthetic baits.

Kepley BioSystems Phase II Accomplishments:

  1. Designed, formulated, and optimized a specialized dissolvable matrix with precision defined release kinetics suitable for use in oceanic environments.The matrix composition of the synthetic bait is critical to dissolution and the rate at which each tablet emits chemosensory molecules intercalated throughout the tablet as it breaks down. Calibrated matrix release parameters were established for diverse fishing operations, crustacean species, and geographic locations. These matrix formulations can be tailored to specific species and diverse aquatic ecosystems with calibrated release rates, regardless of ecosystem, season, water temperature, depth, or other ecological variables.
  2. Identified, characterized and isolated the molecular emission from commonly used non-fish-based bait sources. Each molecule was evaluated for chemotactic potential and ability to lure and attract a crustacean to a specific location or trap.
  3. Identified, characterized and isolated the molecules the molecules released from forage fish bait sources. Isolated and quantified novel attractant compounds that are generated by decaying matter and stimulate crustacean attraction and chemosensory behavior.
  4. Conducted and optimize capture efficiency alongside field participants with commercial fishing operations and regional fishing communities to create the first synthetic and "surrogate" fish bait that released specific chemosensory molecules at calibrated rates. This synthetic and sustainable bait precisely mimics the attractive potential of bait fish and was engineered to meet critical industry pain-points associated with cost, spoilage, refrigeration and stability.

To learn more about OrganoBait visit Kepley BioSystems.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2018
Modified by: Anthony L Dellinger

    OrganoBait Field Testing
  • Forage fish are an important keystone species responsible for the transfer of energy that provides sustenance to nearly all higher marine species.

    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Anthony L Dellinger
    Forage Fish are a keystone species
  • Dr. Dellinger and NSF sponsored REU student, Jordan Gannon, perform molecular analysis to determine chemosensory identification on forage fish used as bait.
    Kepley BioSystems Inc

  • Dr. Anthony Dellinger, Kepley BioSystems Inc President
    University of North Carolina Greensboro
    Anthony L Dellinger
    Dr. Anthony Dellinger
  • Chemosensory molecules released from decaying bait samples using HPLC. These molecules trigger the foraging instincts hardwired into crustacean biology, potentially luring them to a trap for capture.
    Kepley BioSystems Inc
